TL;DR
Overly padded gameplay, annoying characters, beautiful yet heavily padded game.

Long Review:
At first I was in love with it. Within the first few minutes I was like take my money and bought Rebirth. Then I actually got into the game and realized it was irritating. 

Ai/Combat: 
The combat ranges from it's alright, to OMG just work already! The mix of active time battle (wait your  turn) with real time movement is disjointed. The rest of the party either has to be micromanaged or is a liability. Also your Ai companions WILL walk into hazards. Learned that the hard way in the very first mission as Barrett enjoyed face slamming into frickin' laser beams like an Alien Face Hugger trying to escape it's jar. But as annoying as he was, I wanted him to die.

Story:
If there are two words I'd describe the story, it'd be "heavily padded". Instead of getting right to the story, there are  filler quest like you'd find in an MMO. There are changes to the original story and ends before you even get to Kalm. I played 17 ingame hours and still wasn't at Don Corneo. Most of it were silly side quests and watching Dementors attack the party. Also the bad guy is revealed almost immediately, with pretty much no context.

I did however, like how the devs portrayed how terrible the bombing of reactors would be. 

Now comes the worst part, the characters. Many of the characters are annoying.
Cloud simps over Tifa who uses her vasts tracks of land shall we say to mind control him. She's openly manipulative. Aerith is very pushy. Barrett is so rude that he should be thrown out of an airlock, and Red XII is mostly forgettable (as he was in the original).
Tifa is an airhead who openly uses Cloud and mismanages money. She strings him along to get what she wants. She knows the WMD's she's packin' and isn't afraid the use them. But at least she's fun, if not a little overbearing.

I suggest only buying it on sale. O and it worked on Linux thanks to the hard work of the boffins at WINE and Proton. I use Arch by the way.

I love this game. The original on PS1 was my first real foray into RPGs. I had followed its development but didn't think much of it. I think this game is great and respectful of its origins. It's an all around good time to be had. The battle system is awesome, definitely an accumulation of Final Fantasy's gameplay over the years. It's stylish (it's cool af) and fast paced. It's a mix of turn and action and I think SE got it right. Having played almost every FF up through its current 16 release it's my favorite battle system of them all.  

I haven't had many problems with performance and it looks great at 1440p, 120FPS. Stutters seldom, no drops so far, no crashes in the few hours I've played. I did get a white screen but reloaded and that was gone. It's been a smooth experience for the most part.

The story is ongoing but a bit easier to follow. I've played Rebirth and will only form an opinion when they release the last game. The original story still stands and is best described as a sequel...and I want to replay the original soon too so maybe I'll update the story later. It will keep you interested though, just a fun ride. Make sure you play Rebirth!

Final Fantasy VII Remake is visually stunning and has some incredible soundtracks, however it fails as a video game in creating engaging gameplay and establishing consistent story telling. 

The game has terrible pacing and bad writing, it does not value your time, and between every actually meaningful narrative, is filled with meaningless side quests and slow, tedious, repetitive actions. The combat mechanic is very interesting on its own, it is able to hold enough depth and attacks feel satisfying. But everything about it gets worse when you realize every enemy is made out of sponges and most of the time its just smashing the same button to fill up ATB. (Also which genius from SE thinks using item consumes ATB is a good idea?) Enemy types are very limited in this game and encounters suffer from repetition. Boss designs are horrible, honestly some of the worst boss fight experiences for me, most of them are filled with weird tracking attacks that you cannot dodge, massive area damage that you can not dodge, and crazy hit detection that you cannot dodge. Evading doesn't do anything and blocking is extremely ineffective. It feels like the designers of this game had never considered how the players will actually engage with those enemies, the only thing they seem to care about is how cool are the attacks, (which a lot the results are actually cringy). 

In my opinion, FF7 Remake has an appealing story, excellent combat foundation, which are all backed up by breathtaking visuals and music, however the poor execution in pacing and lazy padding in game design ruins the experience for me.

Final Fantasy VII Remake is honestly close to being a masterpiece. You can feel the love behind every part of it. It shows in the interactions, the dialogue, the animations, the menus, the way NPCs talk,. It is obvious that the people who made this genuinely cared about the original and wanted to bring it into the modern era with passion, not like another remake.

As someone who played the original almost twenty years ago, I can say this with confidence. It is not a perfect game. Some chapters drag for a bit and there are moments that feel like pure filler. The story also takes a new direction that not everyone will agree with. But I actually appreciate that they tried something more ambitious instead of just retelling the exact same plot with nicer graphics. The results are mixed, but it's new and the OG game will always exists.

The combat system is on another level. It feels original, fast and incredibly satisfying. It blends action and strategy in an unique way, and I have yet to see this system on another game. Each character plays completely differently and the game encourages you to switch between them constantly. Add the depth of the materia system and the countless ways to build your team and it becomes something  special. This combat system is easily one of the best in the genre and IMO the first FF to blend action and strategy flawlessly.

And the soundtrack. My god. It is one of the best soundtracks in gaming history. The new music, the remixes, the rearranged themes, everything sounds incredible. Every so on, I used Shazam to add the songs to my playlist, it's that good!

So yes, it has flaws. But the heart behind this game is undeniable. It is fun, emotional, creative and full of care. If you loved the original, you absolutely need to play this.

I was initially extremely excited about the remake of Final Fantasy 7 when it was announced back in the ancient time of 2015. The excitement waned a little as time went on. I had gotten rid of my PS4, so the chances of me getting to play the initial release back in 2020 was low. Which was a bit of a bummer, but I had played the original, so at least there was that. 

The original Final Fantasy 7, while perhaps an over-rated one, was one of my favorites of the series. I specifically saved birthday and Christmas money, bought a used PS1 at my local game shop back in 1999 (two years after the OG release) along with this game. I was so enamored with it that I played all the way up to the first time you go to Shinra HQ. In one sitting... Then realized I couldn't save the game because I neglected to get a memory card. So I went back to the shop, got a memory card and came home to find that the PS1 got turned off and all my progress lost. So I started over immediately and managed to make it through the Slums before I had to save and go to bed for school.

Long story short, I loved the game. The music, the character design, the world. Everything about it. I played it multiple times through. I can see the flaws of the original now that I'm grown up, but I still very much have it as one of my core gaming experiences. I figured I wouldn't be missing anything by skipping the Remake, but Square did some very intriguing things with it. The soundtrack manages to be close to, but not exactly equal to, FF7 OG. It's still very good don't get me wrong. The battle system is fun, albeit pretty much the same as FF15 (which I am cool with. I liked that game, despite its problems.) Graphically, it's really nice to look at. The particle effects, lighting and artistic direction are all great. It's very polished.

The English voice acting manages to (mostly) be good to very good. I find Aerith, Jessie, Biggs, TIfa and Barrett's voice acting to be very good. Cloud also sounds good, and while I have now come to enjoy Sephiroth's VA, he had to grow on me a little bit. I won't delve into spoilers, but I will say there's an awful lot of Sephiroth much earlier on in this game than there was in the original. That manages to be both a criticism and also a positive. On one hand, it changes the flow of the story, but it also gives a little more character to the... Well, the character.

I've actually played through this particular game twice. Once on the PS5, and then again on Steam when I was waiting for Rebirth to release. Both times I enjoyed the experience. Since this is the first in a trilogy of games, they really stretched the Midgar section significantly to where it is the sole location in the game. For those that played the original, Midgar really wasn't AS significant of the story as it is in this version. But they did so in a way that gave some lesser used characters more development and it didn't really hamper the overall experience. Unlike Rebirth, it is a strictly linear game with some side quests. But that does keep it to a more focused experience. 

It's not exactly Final Fantasy 13 hallway simulator (I still think that game gets too much hate) but it is very much focused on keeping you on a path with some back and forth between locations. I don't think it's a bad thing, but it is something to keep in mind. The fair criticisms people have made towards FF13s linearity do apply to this one. If you loved the original game, or you are experiencing the world of FF7 for the first time, this is a definitively good one to play. I was particularly intrigued to see where the story changed compared to the PS1 version. 

Numbered ratings are so arbitrary, but I'd give this game an 8.5 inching ever so close to a 9 out of 10. It refreshes the story and visuals while still staying true to much of the core things OG FF7 did well. Character design, setting, and music.

There are few games I've fully delved into, and I'm happy to say that FF7 Remake is one of them! THAT BEING SAID, the game does have some stark flaws, the most notable being its length. It took me the better part of 25-30 hours to beat this game and another 55ish hours to 100% it, with most of the achievements being INCREDIBLY specific and hard to get. The middle part (specifically Wall Market) can be INCREDIBLY tedious, feels waaayyy unnecessary, and unfortunately seems more like a crowd-pleaser fever dream than an actual contribution to the story. The movement outside of combat is a little annoying too - you will spend a majority of this game running from place to place, with occasional fights scattered here and there. I didn't mind that too much since I enjoyed seeing all the different skyboxes and surrounding areas, but I can see how other players would find it boring.

TL,DR: FF7 Remake is an amazing game with a phenomenal story and visuals that is well worth playing, but you will get a lesson in patience in some sections of the game. negative.review:
This game isn't bad but it still disappointed me in a lot of ways.

Perhaps it's because of the insane praise this game has gotten that made my expectations too high. Perhaps it's because i never played the original so I don't have nostalgia bias. The fact of the matter is I can't judge this game or praise it by how faithful it is to the original version. I can only tell you if it's a good game, or a bad game. And I don't think it's a good game.

[h2] GAMEPLAY [/h2]

By far the biggest disappointment was the gameplay. The fundamentals here are good. It feels satisfying to swing your sword as cloud, to swap materia and synergize abilities, to experience the unique playstyle of every character. But it falls short in building upon those good foundations, choosing instead to rely heavily on basic upgrades and surface level abilities that dont feel very creative or rewarding to master. 

The systems that are supposed to enhance the combat just don't feel flushed out enough to keep your interest, especially not for a game padded out to a 30-hour runtime. The new weapons and materia I got never felt exciting or powerful enough to peak my interest. Most of them are always "deal more damage", "have higher mana", "have higher luck". The armours and items suffer from the same issue, with the necklaces and rings having such little creativity that most of them boil down to "Don't die once per battle", "deal 5% more damage", "deal 5% more magic damage". 

It speaks to a design philosophy that abandons creativity in favour of pure stat progression, and it results in a combat experience that, when stretched out to this game's run time, very quickly begins to feel monotonous and disconnecting. You just never feel any motivation to fully engage in its systems because its basic design discourages you from doing so. It's so detrimental to the experience that once you hit the 8-hour mark, you find yourself just going through the motions on auto pilot as the game keeps throwing combat encounter after combat encounter at you.

[h2] LEVEL DESIGN [/h2]

What really pushes the monotony of this game the most is the level design. I don't want to underscore how much work and effort has gone into this game's environments and their details. This game truly is gorgeous, the cut scenes are impeccable, the lighting and environment design is breath taking. But it's all severely hijacked by an insanely oppressive level design that discourages any exploration outside of its scripted sequences. The sheer number of times I wanted to go out to explore and discover new places just for the game to c0ck block me with a warning and force my character back to the scripted zone is ridiculous. 

And when you do finally get permission to explore some areas, you'll quickly realise there is literally nothing worth exploring. No interesting caves to discover, no hidden bosses to find, no fascinating side quests tucked away to be found. Just extremely linear levels with constant dead ends and the odd few chests that have a boring item inside that you'll forget you ever got. 

it's just not good and by the time you hit the mid section, it begins to suck the life out of everything in this game. Long, padded out corridors that look gorgeous, but are so empty and lifeless. Endlessly re-used sections, like the sewer system, with re-skinned monsters and uninspired traversal that forces you to watch your character slowly squeeze through cracks for the 100th time. There are some puzzles sprinkled in to break the monotony, but they are so basic and worthless. They are literally "go grab the key in the other room to open this door" "move the arm to open up the exit". It is so low effort.

Look some of my favourite titles are linear. I have no problem with linear game design, so long as it's done well and in a way that makes the limited exploration feel rewarding, not oppressive.

[h2] STORY [/h2]

That leaves the biggest offering here and what I believe made most people like this game, the story. The story really does have great highs, but my god is it completely sabotaged by its horrendous pacing. There is so much world & character building here that is developed really well, only for it to crumble under the heavy weight of boring plot points, on the nose dialogue, and dark themes never fully explored. I can see a great story here, I really can. But it is so tragically decimated by its poor execution.

By poor execution, I mean poor pacing with over 10 hours of filler content, Random side characters taking center stage for no reason and rehashed plot beats that completely disconnect you from the story. By poor execution, I mean a lack of subtlety in dialogue, with every character just announcing their feelings, every complexity simplified, every theme spelled out to you as if you're a third grader that can't read between the lines yourself. By poor execution, I mean character archetypes so boring and predictable, you basically know everything about them from their first introduction. Like pretty women that's very kind and caring. Buff man that's a hard ass but also loves his daughter. Main character that's always nonchalant and too cool for school but has a dark past. 

I think by far the worst of it was the weird love triangle the game is so insistent on in-cooperating throughout the story. Its such a bizarre tonal shift when put in contrast with the game's themes of terrorism and corporate greed. Like not 10 minutes after completing a terrorist attack on Shinra, you're on a date with tifa, roaming the city and doing chores as she flirts with you. It is such a jarring experience and it completely defuses any stakes build by the narrative. 

The side missions are also really uninspired. They are literally just fetch quests dressed in a narrative gown, except the narrative gown also still sucks. Go find 5 kids, go kill this monster, go find 3 chocobos. It is bottom of the barrel low effort chores disguised as missions. I have completed all of them and i can confidently tell you they changed absolutely nothing in my experience. Some even made the experience much more monotonous if anything. The minigames were okay atleast.

Look there's a good skeleton here, there really is. But the meat around it is rotten. And unless you have a good tolerance for rotten meat, you will not like this. I certainly did not.

[h2] POSITIVES [/h2]

I know this review has been majorly negative, but I can't stress enough how impressive some things in this game are. The graphics truly are gorgeous, with immersive lighting and vibrant colours that really brings the world and its environments to life. The sound design is crisp, clean, realistic and eargasmic, making every footstep, every spell and every swing of the sword incredibly immersive. The combat fundamentals truly are so satisfying. You can feel the impact of cloud's sword, the recoil of Barret‚Äôs gun, the punches and kicks of Tifa's attacks. It is, on the most basic level, very fun. The sheer scale of content here really is insane, with well over 30 hours of content to sink your teeth into. It's just such a shame a lot of the content is executed poorly or just filler.

[h2] CONCLUSION [/h2]

This game feels like a project with tremendous potential that never managed to leverage its own strengths. The combat has flashes of brilliance but becomes stale long before the credits roll. The world is beautiful but designed in a way that actively works against curiosity. And the story, which should have been the game‚Äôs saving grace, collapses under weak pacing, shallow characterization, and dialogue that refuses to trust the player.

There is a good game buried somewhere under all of this, but it‚Äôs constantly overshadowed by decisions that make the experience feel padded, predictable, and ultimately not fun.

Like many FF7 was my favorite game growing up and it had a formative impact on me in many ways. When the remake was released I bought a PS4 just to play it... and I was pretty disappointed back then. The action game type just feels like a boring slog to me. The real killer was the garbage filler content.

After reading that much of the filler can be bypassed I decided to give it a try on PC, since consoles are a pain anyways. I'm keeping a more open mind about the action system and this time around I think it's OK. Nothing special, no real strategy to anything but hey I'm really just here to get to explore the locations I loved in better detail and to see the characters who I accounted friends with real animation so I don't mind.

Then you get to Sector 7 and hit the filler again. So you can't skip it right away. You pretty much need to do one or two basic quests before it gives you the option to bypass the rest. Do so and select yes on a several warnings and great things proceed... right into another whole filler content area (Jessies' arc). It's so cartoonishly dumb. The new characters thrown in are forgettable trash (motorcycle SOLDIER guy). There are no stakes, you pretty much just arcade your way through defeating (not killing, I'll get to this in a bit) hundreds of guards and dozens of mechs to steal weaker explosives for Jessie to use on the next reactor.

Ok boring action aside. Terrible filler aside. There are three absolutely unrecoverable problems with the remake-
1. No stakes. You're eco-terrorists living in a corporate controlled authoritarian tech Polis in the slums crushed under wealth inequality... but there's now no risk. Apparently you and all the characters right at the beginning of the game can defeat any number of opponents without suffering serious injury or death. There are a bunch of side characters doing the eco-terrorism gig too and them vs Shinra might as well be a sport league. It takes the darkness and hopelessness of Midgar that Avalanche is the idealistic core of dreamers who are the few who actually risk everything to make change (and are demonized for it) and ... now everyone in the city is on your side practically. Most everyone is on an Avalanche team it seems and regularly beats up Shinra guards with no consequences.

2. No death. There are scenes specifically clarifying that after cloud slices a group up with his sword that they are just knocked out and not dead. The story would have you believe that you in your violent idealistic terroristic assaults kill nobody. It's all just black and white, good guys vs bad guys with no hard choices and no real consequences. It takes heady topics and complex grey areas of the original and washes them into mindless nothing.

3. The characters don't act consistently. I, like many of you, feel like I know these characters. Not just from replaying the original multiple times but from other content that came out as well (Dirge of Cerberus, Advent Children, Crisis Core [where some of these problems started]) and the core of these characters is not maintained at all in this rendition. Cloud has been softened from a JPop unsociable sociopath who learns to love and care to instead just be a milk-warm nothing of a protagonist. He helps everyone with little to no hope of a reward. He's politely joking and silly all the time from the start. There's no journey without his beginning misanthropy. He's not relatable without the unraveling of his spiky (heh) exterior  as you learn about his traumatic history. I could provide dozens of examples for lines or other characters but this is already getting long.

The gameplay could have sucked (as it does) and I wouldn't have minded. They could have filled it was more garbage filler than actual game and since it's skippable (if you know when and how to select those skips) I wouldn't mind too much. But as this is, it's lost all of its meaning, all of its gritty risk and introspective philosophy (hell the whole story is about being eco-terrorists trying to save the world while innocent bystanders sometimes end up as collateral damage!) and it's lost the core motivations and complex nuances of the characters.

Overall it's a shameless cash-grab most of the time, with some really lovingly recreated content that requires you struggling through so much useless garbage to get to.

This game isn't bad but it still disappointed me in a lot of ways.

Perhaps it's because of the insane praise this game has gotten that made my expectations too high. Perhaps it's because i never played the original so I don't have nostalgia bias. The fact of the matter is I can't judge this game or praise it by how faithful it is to the original version. I can only tell you if it's a good game, or a bad game. And I don't think it's a good game.

[h2] GAMEPLAY [/h2]

By far the biggest disappointment was the gameplay. The fundamentals here are good. It feels satisfying to swing your sword as cloud, to swap materia and synergize abilities, to experience the unique playstyle of every character. But it falls short in building upon those good foundations, choosing instead to rely heavily on basic upgrades and surface level abilities that dont feel very creative or rewarding to master. 

The systems that are supposed to enhance the combat just don't feel flushed out enough to keep your interest, especially not for a game padded out to a 30-hour runtime. The new weapons and materia I got never felt exciting or powerful enough to peak my interest. Most of them are always "deal more damage", "have higher mana", "have higher luck". The armours and items suffer from the same issue, with the necklaces and rings having such little creativity that most of them boil down to "Don't die once per battle", "deal 5% more damage", "deal 5% more magic damage". 

It speaks to a design philosophy that abandons creativity in favour of pure stat progression, and it results in a combat experience that, when stretched out to this game's run time, very quickly begins to feel monotonous and disconnecting. You just never feel any motivation to fully engage in its systems because its basic design discourages you from doing so. It's so detrimental to the experience that once you hit the 8-hour mark, you find yourself just going through the motions on auto pilot as the game keeps throwing combat encounter after combat encounter at you.

[h2] LEVEL DESIGN [/h2]

What really pushes the monotony of this game the most is the level design. I don't want to underscore how much work and effort has gone into this game's environments and their details. This game truly is gorgeous, the cut scenes are impeccable, the lighting and environment design is breath taking. But it's all severely hijacked by an insanely oppressive level design that discourages any exploration outside of its scripted sequences. The sheer number of times I wanted to go out to explore and discover new places just for the game to c0ck block me with a warning and force my character back to the scripted zone is ridiculous. 

And when you do finally get permission to explore some areas, you'll quickly realise there is literally nothing worth exploring. No interesting caves to discover, no hidden bosses to find, no fascinating side quests tucked away to be found. Just extremely linear levels with constant dead ends and the odd few chests that have a boring item inside that you'll forget you ever got. 

it's just not good and by the time you hit the mid section, it begins to suck the life out of everything in this game. Long, padded out corridors that look gorgeous, but are so empty and lifeless. Endlessly re-used sections, like the sewer system, with re-skinned monsters and uninspired traversal that forces you to watch your character slowly squeeze through cracks for the 100th time. There are some puzzles sprinkled in to break the monotony, but they are so basic and worthless. They are literally "go grab the key in the other room to open this door" "move the arm to open up the exit". It is so low effort.

Look some of my favourite titles are linear. I have no problem with linear game design, so long as it's done well and in a way that makes the limited exploration feel rewarding, not oppressive.

[h2] STORY [/h2]

That leaves the biggest offering here and what I believe made most people like this game, the story. The story really does have great highs, but my god is it completely sabotaged by its horrendous pacing. There is so much world & character building here that is developed really well, only for it to crumble under the heavy weight of boring plot points, on the nose dialogue, and dark themes never fully explored. I can see a great story here, I really can. But it is so tragically decimated by its poor execution.

By poor execution, I mean poor pacing with over 10 hours of filler content, Random side characters taking center stage for no reason and rehashed plot beats that completely disconnect you from the story. By poor execution, I mean a lack of subtlety in dialogue, with every character just announcing their feelings, every complexity simplified, every theme spelled out to you as if you're a third grader that can't read between the lines yourself. By poor execution, I mean character archetypes so boring and predictable, you basically know everything about them from their first introduction. Like pretty women that's very kind and caring. Buff man that's a hard ass but also loves his daughter. Main character that's always nonchalant and too cool for school but has a dark past. 

I think by far the worst of it was the weird love triangle the game is so insistent on in-cooperating throughout the story. Its such a bizarre tonal shift when put in contrast with the game's themes of terrorism and corporate greed. Like not 10 minutes after completing a terrorist attack on Shinra, you're on a date with tifa, roaming the city and doing chores as she flirts with you. It is such a jarring experience and it completely defuses any stakes build by the narrative. 

The side missions are also really uninspired. They are literally just fetch quests dressed in a narrative gown, except the narrative gown also still sucks. Go find 5 kids, go kill this monster, go find 3 chocobos. It is bottom of the barrel low effort chores disguised as missions. I have completed all of them and i can confidently tell you they changed absolutely nothing in my experience. Some even made the experience much more monotonous if anything. The minigames were okay atleast.

Look there's a good skeleton here, there really is. But the meat around it is rotten. And unless you have a good tolerance for rotten meat, you will not like this. I certainly did not.

[h2] POSITIVES [/h2]

I know this review has been majorly negative, but I can't stress enough how impressive some things in this game are. The graphics truly are gorgeous, with immersive lighting and vibrant colours that really brings the world and its environments to life. The sound design is crisp, clean, realistic and eargasmic, making every footstep, every spell and every swing of the sword incredibly immersive. The combat fundamentals truly are so satisfying. You can feel the impact of cloud's sword, the recoil of Barret‚Äôs gun, the punches and kicks of Tifa's attacks. It is, on the most basic level, very fun. The sheer scale of content here really is insane, with well over 30 hours of content to sink your teeth into. It's just such a shame a lot of the content is executed poorly or just filler.

[h2] CONCLUSION [/h2]

This game feels like a project with tremendous potential that never managed to leverage its own strengths. The combat has flashes of brilliance but becomes stale long before the credits roll. The world is beautiful but designed in a way that actively works against curiosity. And the story, which should have been the game‚Äôs saving grace, collapses under weak pacing, shallow characterization, and dialogue that refuses to trust the player.

There is a good game buried somewhere under all of this, but it‚Äôs constantly overshadowed by decisions that make the experience feel padded, predictable, and ultimately not fun.

For all the praise surrounding Final Fantasy VII Remake Integrade, I walked away feeling more frustrated than fulfilled. 

And because of that, I do not recommend it.

I was going to give this game a weak recommendation, but on writing this review, I can't really find enough good to outweigh the bad. But let's start with some stuff the game did right. And that's pretty much the visuals (very cool) and the music (decent ambient music but pretty forgettable). Some of the boss fights and enemies felt pretty unique. I actually started playing this game as the MTG set for Final Fantasy released, having known absolutely nothing about the franchise, and it was really cool to see all the references to characters in this game. Unfortunately, that's pretty much where the good ends.

Let's start with the overall gameplay. Combat feels clunky. Dodging is useless for like 90% of the game. A lot of enemy attacks will hit regardless of where you dodge so you really are better off just blocking most of the time or trying to hide behind cover. Some enemies have weaknesses/resistances and you can cast spells but since most fights just were not very engaging, it devolves into mashing the attack button and occasionally throwing in a basic spell or ability. They have a "summon" system, which was pretty cool but without much variety, and if the fight doesn't go long you don't even get to use it.

Movement is pretty bad as well, and even worse outside of combat as you're forced to run long distances with a really crappy minimap (which on keyboard controls is really unintuitive to enable). There's a lot of "forced movement cutscenes", like moving through a tight gap, trying to climb over something. While that's cool the first time, when it happens for the 100th time you wish you could just skip it (you can't). There's not really a simple way to backtrack, so you end up just having to run there. 

This segues nicely into side quests, which is probably among the worst things in the game. Actually, part of the reason I couldn't get into FF14 was because it just felt like an endless train of fetch quests. Well, they brought that into FF7 Remake and they are largely just glorified fetch quests without discernible quest markers. I actually had to take breaks after certain chapters because they were so excruciatingly boring and tedious. There was a *lot* of running around without easy backtracking (except on quest completion, they let you teleport). I would say don't bother with these, they are a complete waste of time and often offer incredibly little narrative value.

The entire narrative was riddled with more plot holes than Cloud should be after getting peppered by Shinra reinforcements  cotton bullets. The villains (Heidegger, Don Corneo, Hojo) are so comically incompetent at their jobs and so moustache-twirling evil it's impossible to take them seriously. If any of these villains rubbed their 2 brain cells together none of the plot would have happened, because our heroes would have gunned down. There's no nuance in their characters, no real logic in their motivations. A classic case of evil for evil's sake. 

How about the heroes? Cloud and Tifa feel pretty much like non-characters. Cloud starts off aloof and is generally dismissive of others. Cloud ends slightly less aloof and is sort of nicer to his friends. Tifa starts off as a nice person who cares for her friends, and ends in the exact same place. She doesn't have any memorable moments and is basically there to look pretty. Barret does undergo a minor arc, and despite starting out hating him, he seemed to allow his ideals to change as he saw the consequences of his actions. Aerith was also a nuanced character and had more complex motivations, though acts more to change Cloud and Barret than actually changing herself.

I was talking with a friend the other day about this, and came to the realization that if I compared this game to Genshin Impact, it does almost nothing better. Visuals are maybe slightly worse, but everything else? For Genshin, gameplay is deeper, story is rich, characters have nuance, quests are more interesting. So aside from getting some cultural education for playing this game, it really doesn't offer very much. Overall, I'd give this a 5/10, bumped up to a 5.5/10 since at least they made Aerith and Tifa pretty attractive.

Like many FF7 was my favorite game growing up and it had a formative impact on me in many ways. When the remake was released I bought a PS4 just to play it... and I was pretty disappointed back then. The action game type just feels like a boring slog to me. The real killer was the garbage filler content.

After reading that much of the filler can be bypassed I decided to give it a try on PC, since consoles are a pain anyways. I'm keeping a more open mind about the action system and this time around I think it's OK. Nothing special, no real strategy to anything but hey I'm really just here to get to explore the locations I loved in better detail and to see the characters who I accounted friends with real animation so I don't mind.

Then you get to Sector 7 and hit the filler again. So you can't skip it right away. You pretty much need to do one or two basic quests before it gives you the option to bypass the rest. Do so and select yes on a several warnings and great things proceed... right into another whole filler content area (Jessies' arc). It's so cartoonishly dumb. The new characters thrown in are forgettable trash (motorcycle SOLDIER guy). There are no stakes, you pretty much just arcade your way through defeating (not killing, I'll get to this in a bit) hundreds of guards and dozens of mechs to steal weaker explosives for Jessie to use on the next reactor.

Ok boring action aside. Terrible filler aside. There are three absolutely unrecoverable problems with the remake-
1. No stakes. You're eco-terrorists living in a corporate controlled authoritarian tech Polis in the slums crushed under wealth inequality... but there's now no risk. Apparently you and all the characters right at the beginning of the game can defeat any number of opponents without suffering serious injury or death. There are a bunch of side characters doing the eco-terrorism gig too and them vs Shinra might as well be a sport league. It takes the darkness and hopelessness of Midgar that Avalanche is the idealistic core of dreamers who are the few who actually risk everything to make change (and are demonized for it) and ... now everyone in the city is on your side practically. Most everyone is on an Avalanche team it seems and regularly beats up Shinra guards with no consequences.

2. No death. There are scenes specifically clarifying that after cloud slices a group up with his sword that they are just knocked out and not dead. The story would have you believe that you in your violent idealistic terroristic assaults kill nobody. It's all just black and white, good guys vs bad guys with no hard choices and no real consequences. It takes heady topics and complex grey areas of the original and washes them into mindless nothing.

3. The characters don't act consistently. I, like many of you, feel like I know these characters. Not just from replaying the original multiple times but from other content that came out as well (Dirge of Cerberus, Advent Children, Crisis Core [where some of these problems started]) and the core of these characters is not maintained at all in this rendition. Cloud has been softened from a JPop unsociable sociopath who learns to love and care to instead just be a milk-warm nothing of a protagonist. He helps everyone with little to no hope of a reward. He's politely joking and silly all the time from the start. There's no journey without his beginning misanthropy. He's not relatable without the unraveling of his spiky (heh) exterior  as you learn about his traumatic history. I could provide dozens of examples for lines or other characters but this is already getting long.

The gameplay could have sucked (as it does) and I wouldn't have minded. They could have filled it was more garbage filler than actual game and since it's skippable (if you know when and how to select those skips) I wouldn't mind too much. But as this is, it's lost all of its meaning, all of its gritty risk and introspective philosophy (hell the whole story is about being eco-terrorists trying to save the world while innocent bystanders sometimes end up as collateral damage!) and it's lost the core motivations and complex nuances of the characters.

Overall it's a shameless cash-grab most of the time, with some really lovingly recreated content that requires you struggling through so much useless garbage to get to.

This remake is eye candy, there's no denying that, but when everything else is either mediocre or just down right awful, I fail to see why this game even got made (aside from money).

This unholy obsession that modern games have with replicating this GTA/RDR2 style movement where everything has to look as realistic as possible really has to go. Wanna do an action? You have to wait until you character settles into an idle position, which will basically happen every single time. I seriously don't see an issue with making sure regular gameplay doesn't require such animation, it can just be saved for cutscenes, since there are a TON of them. If I wanted to see how cool it is to observe intricate movements and realistic sun beams, I'd go outside.

The combat, while flashy, gets repetitive especially when you have to repeat the same three things every encounter. I understand turn based RPGs are like this in nature, but this ditches that formula in favor of something more action oriented.

The music is great. I was really fond of the Collapsed Expressway theme. To be honest I'm not really all that impressed since this is a Final Fantasy game.

We have GOT to get Nomura out of the director chair.

The actual story is questionable. Sephiroth shows up every other two hours and it feels like they only incorporated him for fan service. Instead of being something that is accessible for people who have or haven't played the original FFVII, it's weirdly catered towards OG fans especially because Zack shows up near the end alive and well, and I really doubt newcomers know who Zack is.

I'm also unsure why they sometimes opt for pre rendered cutscenes when there are already so many in-engine cutscenes that look as good if not better.
